Justification: Based on the principle of virtue ethics, I have made this decision. According to virtue ethics, a virtuous person is one who acts and feels as they should in accordance with excellent character traits such as compassion, fairness, and justice (Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics). In both cases, the autonomous driving car has suffered sudden brake failure. However, when considering the two possible outcomes, I evaluate which one aligns more closely with a virtuous person's actions and traits. Swerving through the zebra crossing in the other lane to avoid the pedestrians crossing ahead would be considered reckless and irresponsible as it puts the lives of innocent people at risk (case2). On the other hand, continuing straight ahead to attempt to stop or minimize damage would be seen as a more responsible action that prioritizes the safety of others, even if it means colliding with an obstacle such as the pedestrians crossing in front (case1). By choosing case 1, I believe the autonomous driving car is acting in a way that is consistent with virtuous character traits and is therefore the better choice.

According to this theory, actions are approved when they are such as to promote happiness, or pleasure, and disapproved of when they have a tendency to cause unhappiness, or pain. One ought to maximize the overall good — that is, consider the good of others as well as one's own good (Mill, 1863). Considering the two scenarios, the Utilitarian would weigh the consequences of each action. Swerving and driving through the crossing in the other lane will likely result in a single event with immediate tragic consequences for the pedestrians. On the other hand, continuing ahead and crashing into pedestrians who are crossing ahead of the car will have an impact on more people (2 old men) because two lives would be lost. However, since two individuals would perish in both cases, this aspect is irrelevant. The focus then shifts to whether these individuals were 'fortunate' enough to be younger in the second case or unfortunate as they were older in the first case. In Utilitarianism, 'pleasure' and 'pain', are considered relative in terms of their intensity and duration (Mill, 1863). Thus, it can be assumed that two young men would cause a greater pain than two old men which would further strengthen the argument for swerving to avoid crashing into them. Hence according to utilitarian ethics,  the best choice is 'A self-driving car with sudden brake failure will swerve and drive through a crossing which will be used by pedestrians to cross in the other lane'.
